articles.author: ABBY SEWELL and NATALIE MELZER
articles.description: BEIRUT (AP) — Hezbollah's acting leader vowed Monday to continue battling Israel and said the militant group was prepared for a long fight even after much of its top command was wiped out, including its leader, Hassan Nasrallah.
articles.title: Hezbollah's acting leader vows to fight on after Nasrallah's death

articles.author: KAREEM CHEHAYEB and JACK JEFFERY
articles.description: BEIRUT (AP) — In just over a week, intensified Israeli strikes in Lebanon killed seven high-ranking commanders and officials from the powerful Hezbollah militant group, including the group's leader, Hassan Nasrallah.
articles.title: Who were the 7 high-ranking Hezbollah officials killed over the past week?

articles.author: KATE PAYNE, JEFFREY COLLINS and PATRICK WHITTLE
articles.description: PERRY, Fla. (AP) — North Carolina officials pledged to get more water and other supplies to flood-stricken areas by Monday after Hurricane Helene left a trail of destruction across the U.S.
articles.title: Supplies rushed to communities isolated by Helene as death toll rises to nearly 100

articles.author: WILL WEISSERT and COLLEEN LONG
articles.description: LAS VEGAS (AP) — Vice President Kamala Harris poked at Donald Trump over crowd sizes, his refusal to debate again and his privileged background on Sunday as she hauled in campaign cash in California and held a raucous rally at the same Nevada venue where the Republican nominee had appeared just two weeks ago.
articles.title: Harris trolls Trump at Vegas rally and LA fundraiser, says her crowds are 'pretty big'

articles.author: REBECCA SANTANA
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — Republicans are pointing to newly released immigration enforcement data to bolster their argument that the Biden administration is letting migrants who have committed serious crimes go free in the U.S. But the numbers have been misconstrued without key context.
articles.title: Trump is pointing to new numbers on migrants with criminal pasts. Here's what they show

articles.author: MARI YAMAGUCHI
articles.description: TOKYO (AP) — Shigeru Ishiba, the head of Japan's governing party, plans to call a parliamentary election to be held on Oct.
articles.title: Japan's likely next leader says he will call an election for Oct. 27 once he takes office

articles.description: MANILA, Philippines (AP) — A powerful typhoon was lashing the northernmost islands of the Philippines Monday, prompting officials to evacuate villagers, shut down schools and inter-island ferries and warn of “potentially very destructive” damage to coastal villages.
articles.title: A powerful typhoon is lashing northern Philippine islands

articles.author: DAVID RISING
articles.description: BANGKOK (AP) — Indonesian shrimp farmer Yulius Cahyonugroho operated more than two dozen ponds only a few years ago, employing seven people and making more than enough to support his family. Since then, the 39-year-old says the prices he gets from purchasers have fallen by half and he's had to scale back to four workers and about one-third the ponds, some months not even breaking even.
articles.title: As big supermarkets pursue profits, new research shows growing exploitation of shrimp farmers

articles.author: ANDREW DALTON and KRISTIN M. HALL
articles.description: LOS ANGELES (AP) — Kris Kristofferson, a Rhodes scholar with a deft writing style and rough charisma who became a country music superstar and an A-list Hollywood actor, has died.Kristofferson died at his home on Maui, Hawaii, on Saturday, family spokeswoman Ebie McFarland said in an email.
articles.title: Kris Kristofferson, singer-songwriter and actor, dies at 88

articles.author: JILL LAWLESS
articles.description: LONDON (AP) — Britain’s last coal-fired power plant is closing on Monday, ending 142 years of coal-generated electricity in the nation that sparked the Industrial Revolution.
articles.title: Britain's last coal-fired electricity plant is closing. It ends 142 years of coal power in the UK
